I was discussing this with some guys today and thought I would post it here and see what you all thought.
 
 During the Vietnam war and in some analysis aterwards, there was some speculation that we lost in vietnam because America had grown too big for it's britches. We did not believe that we could be defeated, and we planned our strategy accordingly. Even later in the war when we were getting our butts handed to us pretty well, we simply could not accept the fact that we were unable to take a little, undeveloped nation. Richard Nixon stood ont he whitehouse steps and said "Victory in southeast asia is assured" while their flag was flying over our embassy in Saigon. 
 
 After the breakup of the Soviet Union, there were rumors that several other nations (that we considered friendly) were assisting the VC by funneling funds through the Soviet Union because, although they did not support communism, they did want to see a loss by America to get us back in line. No country feels comfortable if they see another, especially one with the kind of military power that the US has, running roughshod over the entire planet.
 
 I saw an international poll at people-press a while back that showed that over 70% of those polled considered themselves to be "strongly anti-american". According to the poll, even the Dutch were strongly anti American. Majorities in 7 of 8 predominatly mulim countries believe the US will someday pose a threat to theri country, and internationally the US was #4 on the list of "who is the greatest threat to world peace" as rated by citizens of the european union.
 
 There is a new poll out now, but I haven't had time to review it.
 
 Anyway, the question is, do you think America is getting too big for its britches, and do you think this will lead to more complications on the international front? The response to this question when asked earlier was pretty evenly divided between "screw the rest of the world, there is no country int he world that can take us", and "maybe we need to practice a little more restraint in our foreign policy".
 
 While I would certainly agree that there is probably no country in the world that can match us militarily, how about any 2 countries, or 5, or 10? What about after they cut off our middle eastern oil supply?
 
 Your thoughts?
